comments.body:
I don't think this would ever trigger. The `argument_spec` doesn't list `message`, so it would never be accepted to get to this point.

We would either have to allow it as an alias, or use `check_invalid_arguments=False`, which would potentially cause larger issues.
This will be useful for users to migrate from 'message' to respective parameter argument. I can add alias 'message' in arg spec and set it on the path of deprecation.
Yes, I agree with the intent, just without allowing `message` in the `argument_spec`, this path would never fire. You would get an invalid parameter error as is.

Shouldn’t we add a control in AnsibleModule (or any better place in Core) that makes sure that « message » is not used in the future ?

As far as I know (could be wrong) there is no documented list of forbidden keys in argument_spec. So we should document this, maybe in the module dev guide ?
@rrey I updated developer guide and add a check in `validate-modules` to check existence of restricted parameter name in module argument spec.
